channel.title: Machine Learning on Sebastián Ayala Ruano
channel.description: Recent content in Machine Learning on Sebastián Ayala Ruano

item.title: Prediction of the phenological stages of tropical forest species using herbarium records
item.description: I contributed to this project as part of my work as data scientist consultant at Universidad de las Américas, in Ecuador. Summary The initial species list comprised 636 unique names, which were filtered to delete duplicates and records identified at a genus level. The final list comprised 438 accepted names verified based on the Checklist of the Vascular Plants of the Americas (CVPA), publicly available on a website on the Missouri Botanical Garden database Tropicos.

item.title: Prediction of antimicrobial peptides using machine learning classifiers
item.description: I developed this project as the Capstone assignment for the Machine Learning Zoomcamp. Figure 1.- 3D-structure of an antimicrobial peptide. Background Antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) are small bioactive drugs, commonly with fewer than 50 amino acids, which have appeared as promising compounds to control infectious disease caused by multi-drug resistant bacteria or superbugs. These superbugs are not treatable with the available drugs because of the development of some mechanisms to avoid the action of these compounds, which is known as antimicrobial resistance (AMR).

item.title: The molecular basis of JAZ-MYC coupling, a protein-protein interface essential for plant response to stressors
item.description: This presentation was awarded as the best oral presentation of the symposium. In this section you can find more details about this project.

item.title: Corn Disease Detector
item.description: This project was built as a final group assignment during the Saturdays AI Quito 2021 artificial intelligence workshop. Figure 1.- Logo of the Corn Disease Detector project. Retrieved from https://corndiseasedetector.github.io/. Background Infectious diseases are a major threat for many crops of high importance for the food security of many regions of the world. Each year, around 60% of farmers in Ecuador have reported pre-harvest losses due to infectious agents such as fungi and bacteria, in crops like banana, cacao, and potato.

item.title: Prediction of potential drug ligands that bind to Beta-Lactamases
item.description: I developed this project as the Midterm assignment for the Machine Learning Zoomcamp. Data Professor proposed the idea and dataset of this initiative, a collaborative Open Bioinformatics Research Project that is still in progress. Figure 1.- 3D-structure of a betalactamase (PDB ID: 2q9n). Retrieved from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:PDB_2q9n_EBI.png. Used under a CC0 licence. Background This project aims to evaluate the activity of molecules that have been experimentally tested to bind or not bind to Beta-Lactamases.

item.title: Sentiment analysis of Ecuadorian political tweets from 2021 elections
item.description: This project was developed as a final group assignment during the Artificial Intelligence course at my bachelor, which I took as requirement for obtaining of my minor in Systems Engineering. Figure 1.- Natural Language Processing illustration. Retrieved from https://thenounproject.com/term/natural-language-processing/3261011/. Used under a CC-BY 4.0 licence. Summary In this project, we captured sentiments of replies to tweets from two Ecuadorian presidential candidates in the 2021 elections (@LassoGuillermo and @ecuarauz). A model of neural networks was used to classify tweets considering their sentiment as positive, negative, or neutral.

item.title: The molecular basis of JAZ-MYC coupling, a key component of plant immunity
item.description: I worked on this project during my bachelor, collaborating as undergraduate researcher at the Computational and Theoretical Chemistry Group - Universidad San Francisco de Quito, in Ecuador. Summary The jasmonic acid (JA) signaling pathway is one of the primary mechanisms that allow plants to respond to a variety of biotic and abiotic stressors. Within this pathway, the JAZ repressor proteins and the basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factor MYC3 play a critical role.
